items.title: Maintenance status?
items.body:
Thank you for the excellent work on this project, it's a package that I use in another open source project with many happy users. 

I was wondering about the status of this project, there hasn't been a commit to master for 6 months and the current version does not work with Django 3.0 which is going to be released today. There is a PR which is waiting to add compatibility (#524) but it doesn't look like it has been reviewed. 

Is there anything that we can do to help? If the maintainers no longer have the time to do this (totally understandable!), maybe it could be moved to an organisation to support this project support this such as JazzBand? Thanks again :-)

items.title: FEATURE REQUEST: Adding support for WEBP images
items.body:
Current version of **easy-thumbnails doesn't support Webp images**. WebP lossless images are 26% smaller in size compared to PNGs and WebP lossy images are 25-34% smaller than comparable JPEG images at equivalent quality.

Honestly I don't know if this would be hard to implement or not, but Webp probably is going to become a web standard at some stage, therefore adding support for this format would be a great improvement.

items.title: Have easy-thumbnails regenerate thumbnail if source image is changed
items.body: It would be really helpful to have easy-thumbnails automatically regenerate the thumbnail when any kind of save action occurs on the ImageField. I've had issues where it still serves the old thumbnail after the source image has been changed.

items.title: Compatibility issue with Django 3.0 due to django.utils.six
items.body:
Django 3.0 scheduled for December removed Python 2 compatibility API used by easy-thumbnails (django.utils.six).

See https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/releases/3.0/#removed-private-python-2-compatibility-apis
It would be wise to switch now to the direct use of six.

items.title: thumbnail not found
items.body:
```shell
In [3]: p.image                                                                                                                                       
Out[3]: <ImageFieldFile: documents/4/book_of_hours_0.png>

In [5]: get_thumbnailer(p.image).thumbnail_exists(settings.THUMBNAIL_ALIASES['']['card'])                                                            
Out[5]: False

In [6]: name = get_thumbnailer(p.image).get_thumbnail_name(settings.THUMBNAIL_ALIASES['']['card'])                                                   

In [8]: os.path.exists(os.path.join(settings.MEDIA_ROOT, name))                                                                                      
Out[8]: True

In [9]: get_thumbnailer(p.image).thumbnail_exists(settings.THUMBNAIL_ALIASES['']['card'])                                                            
Out[9]: False
```

My use case is, when an image is uploaded I asynchronously create the corresponding thumbnails in a celery task (just calling generate_all_thumbnails). And I am trying to get the url of the thumbnail in a rest api with this snippet:
```python
thbn = get_thumbnailer(img)  # img is a FieldFile
for alias in self.thumbnails:
     config = settings.THUMBNAIL_ALIASES[''][alias]
     if thbn.thumbnail_exists(config):
          data['thumbnails'][alias] = thbn.get_thumbnail(config, generate=False).url
```
But `thbn.thumbnail_exists(config)` always returns False and `thbn.get_thumbnail(config, generate=False)` always returns None i have no idea why since the file does exist on the file system, is in the right place, and no errors where raised by generate_all_thumbnails in the celery task.  

Any idea?

items.title: IOError exception raised when setting THUMBNAIL_TRANSPARENCY_EXTENSION = 'jpg'
items.body:
Before Pillow 4.2.0, attempting to save an RGBA image as JPEG would discard the alpha channel. From Pillow 3.4.0, a deprecation warning was shown. **From Pillow 4.2.0, the deprecation warning is removed and an :py:exc:`IOError` is raised.**

https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/issues/2609
https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/blob/master/docs/releasenotes/4.2.0.rst#id14

items.title: setup.py references 'pillow' instead of 'Pillow'

The setup.py references 'pillow' under-cased. The actual project is 'Pillow', and while that doesn't seem to be an issue usually, it has caused problems in another project I'm working with

See: https://github.com/Miserlou/Zappa/issues/841


Its probably an easy and safe change to reference Pillow with its proper casing in the setup.py

items.title: Pillow dropped Py26 support
items.body:
The test for Django 1.4 makes use of the latest Pillow which doesn't support Python 2.6 and then fails.  I think it can be specified in the tox.ini to import "pillow<4.0.0".

However, pip is going to be dropping 2.6 support so maybe this project should drop support for 2.6 and just change the test to use 2.7.

Discussion on Pillow dropping 2.6 support here:  https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/pull/2192

items.title: Add `easy_thumbnails_tags` templatetag library that mirrors traditional `thumbnail`
items.body:
Add `easy_thumbnails_tags` templatetag library that mirrors traditional thumbnail.

This allows usage of `easy-thumbnails` in templates by {% load easy_thumbnails_tags %} instead of traditional {% load thumbnail %}. It's specifically useful in projects that do make use of multiple thumbnailer libraries (for instance easy-thumbnails alongside sorl-thumbnail).

Works fine in my [fork](https://github.com/barseghyanartur/easy-thumbnails/blob/master/easy_thumbnails/templatetags/easy_thumbnails_tags.py). If you, in principle, have nothing against addition of `easy_thumbnails_tags` mirror, I'll add tests and update the documentation prior making a pull request.

On line https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails/blob/master/easy_thumbnails/processors.py#L106, there's a check that will never pass:

```
if utils.is_transparent(im) and False:
```

I'm trying to decide is someone was debugging/testing a code path and forgot to remove it, or if it's just a bug - but if the code is valuable, it should probably be fixed?

items.title: 1.10 compatibility: thumbnail_cleanup command uses old BaseCommand.option_list
items.body:
The Management Command uses the old  BaseCommand.option_list in `easy_thumbnails/management/commands/thumbnail_cleanup.py Line 124` which causes the thumbnail_cleanup command to fail on django 1.10.

Use https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/howto/custom-management-commands/#accepting-optional-arguments instead.

As a workaround you may uninstall django 1.10, reinstall django 1.9, run the command and than reinstall django 1.10 again :)

items.title: Image dimensions strange when using image with EXIF orientation
items.body:
I am testing my site using easy_thumbnails when using images which have some EXIF orientation (!=1).

I have this file initially saved in a standard django image field (`Image.image_field`):
![example_exif_6_image_v1lafnm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8556593/15607266/7d0de386-2409-11e6-8351-12ce5d7998b4.jpg)

It has EXIF orientation 6!

I then write the following:
`from easy_thumbnails.files import get_thumbnailer
f = image_instance.image_field
thumb = get_thumbnailer(f)
thumb.get_thumbnail({'size': (300, 300)})`

The outputted image looks like this:
![example_exif_6_image_v1lafnm jpg 300x300_q85](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8556593/15607342/f5742c68-2409-11e6-9e01-46127af83932.jpg)

Is this the intended behaviour? Am I doing something wrong? I would expect to either have ignored the EXIF data entirely and kept the image on its side or to have rotated it. What seems to have happened is that the image is rotated and then sliced bits off the side and fleshed out with black areas top and bottom so that it matches the unrotated image's aspect ratio.

items.title: Saner default for THUMBNAIL_DEFAULT_STORAGE
items.body:
A saner default for `THUMBNAIL_DEFAULT_STORAGE` would be `easy_thumbnails.storage.ThumbnailDefaultStorage`. This would cause the thumbnails to be saved on the default storage backend, together with all the other media files. The current default (`easy_thumbnails.storage.ThumbnailFileSystemStorage`) seems too opinionated and not what I would expect after setting a custom `DEFAULT_FILE_STORAGE` (e.g S3).

For this to work the implementation of `easy_thumbnails.storage.ThumbnailDefaultStorage` would have to use django's default storage here: https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails/blob/5dc9c2b7b0fb1c91e17cd3de9ffcb556f5426a71/easy_thumbnails/storage.py#L27

items.title: crop, scale and maintain exact size via low level API
Accessing the field's predefined alias using Django Rest Framework serializer, object has no attribute
items.body:
The [docs on the GitHub page](https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails#fields) suggests that what I'm trying to do should work:

`thumb_url = profile.photo['avatar'].url`

In my project, it gives an error:

```
THUMBNAIL_ALIASES = {
    '': {
        'thumb': {'size': (64, 64), 'upscale': False},
    },
}

class Image(models.Model):
    place = models.ForeignKey(Place, models.CASCADE, 'images')
    image = ThumbnailerImageField(upload_to='')

class ImageSerializer(serializers.Serializer):
    image = serializers.ImageField()
    thumb = serializers.ImageField(source='image["thumb"].url')

AttributeError: Got AttributeError when attempting to get a value for field `thumb` on serializer `ImageSerializer`.
The serializer field might be named incorrectly and not match any attribute or key on the `Image` instance.
Original exception text was: 'ThumbnailerImageFieldFile' object has no attribute 'image["thumb"]'.
```

The url of `image` is serialized properly if `thumb` is removed.
This generates the expected URL in shell: `Image.objects.get(pk=1).image['thumb'].url`
Is there a clean and proper way to access the URL of `thumb` in a DRF serializer?

items.title: Concurrency issue in database_get_image_dimensions
items.body:
Hello, i am hitting concurrency issue in `database_get_image_dimensions`:

https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails/blob/master/easy_thumbnails/files.py#L121-L124

When two requests are running this code and thumbnail dimension record is not present in database yet, first request will save it to the db and the second one will also try to save it (and will fail with integrity error).

```
duplicate key value violates unique constraint "easy_thumbnails_thumbnaildimensions_thumbnail_id_key"
DETAIL:  Key (thumbnail_id)=(73165) already exists.
```

We should probably try to use `get_or_create`.

items.title: THUMBNAIL_CACHE_DIMENSIONS generates invalid query in Django 1.8
items.body:
We updated a project to Django 1.8; if we have THUMBNAIL_CACHE_DIMENSIONS enabled we get an error:

```
Invalid field name(s) given in select_related: 'dimensions'. Choices are: (none)
```

This is probably because Django 1.8 validates the fields passed to select_related:

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.8/releases/1.8/#select-related-now-checks-given-fields

items.title: Incorrect extension passed to custom namer
items.body:
I use a custom namer for my thumbnails. In Settings.py
`THUMBNAIL_NAMER = 'pony.utils.thumbnail_namer'`

Renamer code:

```
import os

def thumbnail_namer(thumbnailer, prepared_options, source_filename, thumbnail_extension, **kwargs):
    # I get fileExtension here as the one that is passed above "thumbnail_extension" is not always correct
    fileName, fileExtension = os.path.splitext(source_filename)
    new_name = source_filename
    suffix = '_medium' +fileExtension;
    new_name = new_name.replace((fileExtension), suffix)
    return new_name
```

I only have 1 thumbnail_alias defined, but have noticed the following:
1. The thumbnail_namer method gets called 3 times per image uploaded - is this expected behavior?
2. The thumbnail_extension passed in is sometimes wrong, reporting jpg when it is a png and resulting in the thumbnail not being generated. I have taken to extracting the file extension myself as a workaround - this seems to be a bug.

items.title: Question: replace_alpha not used?
items.body:
The `replace_alpha` parameter isn't used here: https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails/blob/master/easy_thumbnails/processors.py#L299 - it looks like maybe it's supposed to be usd here: https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails/blob/master/easy_thumbnails/processors.py#L319

Just something I noticed, but maybe it's nothing.

items.title: Thumbnails not generated for files with uppercase extensions
items.body: I am using the latest version of easy-thumbnails and it is working great except that when a user tries to upload an image with an uppercase extension e.g. image.JPG, no thumbnail gets generated. I have confirmed that my simply changing the JPG to jpg, all works well. Please help - not sure how to fix/work around this.

items.title: Possible to use alias name in custom namer?
items.body:
Unless I'm mistaken, you're currently unable to use an alias' name in the generated thumb's filename - it was suggested in https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails/issues/204, but as far as I can tell, the custom namer functionality doesn't support this, as the alias name doesn't get passed in as an option into the namer at https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails/blob/714aa5f36894797ca6c980c9bc8cfa52a46156c1/easy_thumbnails/files.py#L444.

I would think that if the key of the aliases dictionary was added into the options before calling `get_thumbnail` at https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails/blob/714aa5f36894797ca6c980c9bc8cfa52a46156c1/easy_thumbnails/files.py#L91, it would be available for a custom namer then?

Edit: the reason I'm looking for this is to simplify a Rails to Django project rewrite; the legacy Rails app uses 'paperclip', which in turn uses the alias name in its thumbnail filename generation. To make this seamless (I hope), this change would be handy.

items.title: Thumbnail generation fails due to issue with optimize
items.body:
I have optimization turned on for my Django site that uses easy_thumbnails. Here's the configuration in my settings file: 

```
INSTALLED_APPS = (
...
    'easy_thumbnails',
    'easy_thumbnails.optimize',
...
)

THUMBNAIL_DEBUG = False

THUMBNAIL_ALIASES = {
    '': {
        'avatar': {'size': (50, 50), 'crop': True, 'quality': 75},
        'detailcoverimage': {'size': (960,720), 'crop': False, 'quality': 90},
        (etc)...
     },
}

# Thumbnail optimizer
THUMBNAIL_OPTIMIZE_COMMAND = {
    'png': os.path.expanduser("~") + '/bin/optipng {filename}',
    # 'gif': '/usr/bin/optipng {filename}',
    'jpeg': os.path.expanduser("~") + '/bin/jpegoptim {filename}'
}
```

Until recently I had no issues with this. Recently when I go to add new files which should get thumbnails generated, it doesn't work - no thumbnail files show up in the relevant directory, and when using the `thumbnail_url` filter in a template, a blank string is returned. 

I tried generating thumbnails manually from the command line using `easy_thumbnails.files.generate_all_aliases`, and got the following message:

```
>>> easy_thumbnails.files.generate_all_aliases(image,True)
No handlers could be found for logger "easy_thumbnails.optimize"
```

The thumbnails were generated, and the `thumbnail_url` filter started working again for the specific image that I manually generated all aliases for. Uploading a new image resulted in the problem reappearing.

Disabling all optimization (by commenting out the `easy_thumbnails.optimize` app and all of the optimize command configuration) removes the problem. This works for now but I would like to have optimization enabled.

I am using the following versions of relevant apps:
- Django 1.6.10
- Pillow 2.7.0
- easy-thumbnails 2.2

items.title: Weirdest issue: {% thumbnail ... %} works great in Chrome, fails on Safari, Mobile Safari, Firefox
items.body: So. I have a Filer image and I render it in my template as: `{% thumbnail instance.hero_image "1200x0" as hero %} ... `. Works great... I actually have about 7 of these in my template, one for each section of my web page. All are the same size. ('instance' in this case is a page Section). Test in Safari. No images appear save 1. Weird. Look at the source in Safari. The url is empty for all of them, except the one, which looks quite normal. This issue is repeatable over multiple reloads and on Safari, mobile Safari and Firefox. But repeatedly works peachy on Chrome. Hmm, ok, perhaps this is some sort of weird ad-blocking or malware prevention thing? So, I copy the resulting URL from my Chrome browser: `/media/filer_public_thumbnails/filer_public/39/49/394937a1-8512-4192-aff9-895d646b1423/lidehome-tall-cropped.jpg__1200x0_q95_subsampling-2.jpg` And paste it into a new HTML comment tag `` in my template verbatim. Renders fine in all browers. Next, I copy the same URL above into my View as a context property 'test' and render it using `{{ test }}` renders fine in all browsers. It isn't clear to me how, but it seems that something in Safari, Firefox is actively breaking `{% thumbnail ... %}`? Here's the relevant request headers from Safari for the page request: Accept text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,_/_;q=0.8 User-Agent Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_8_5) AppleWebKit/600.1.17 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/6.2 Safari/537.85.10 Here's the relevant request headers from Firefox for the page request: Accept:"text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,_/_;q=0.8" Accept-Language:"bg,en-us;q=0.8,fr-fr;q=0.5,en;q=0.3" User-Agent:"Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.8; rv:27.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/27.0" Accept-Encoding:"gzip, deflate" Wait... now Chrome is doing it...

items.title: Possible missing migration?
items.body:
Using version 2.1 and Django 1.7. Running initial migrate management command runs through the 2 thumbnail migrations. I noticed that when running makemigrations for other project work creates a new migration for thumbnails.:

```
Migrations for 'easy_thumbnails':
  0003_auto_20140918_2106.py:
    - Alter field source on thumbnail
    - Alter field thumbnail on thumbnaildimensions
```

The migration file looks like:

``` python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
from __future__ import unicode_literals

from django.db import models, migrations


class Migration(migrations.Migration):

    dependencies = [
        ('easy_thumbnails', '0002_thumbnaildimensions'),
    ]

    operations = [
        migrations.AlterField(
            model_name='thumbnail',
            name='source',
            field=models.ForeignKey(related_name=b'thumbnails', to='easy_thumbnails.Source'),
        ),
        migrations.AlterField(
            model_name='thumbnaildimensions',
            name='thumbnail',
            field=models.OneToOneField(related_name=b'dimensions', to='easy_thumbnails.Thumbnail'),

```

items.title: add an option to preserve the color profile
items.body: `easy-thumbnails` does not copy the icc profile from the source image to the thumbnails it generates. It should be easy to do it: get the  `src_image.info` dict then put it back when the new image is saved.
